Russia has long employed a modular toolkit of economic, political, informational, and covert action-based “hostile measures” to advance Russian interests by influencing European policies and publics. Since Russia’s 2014 invasion of Crimea and Donbas, European governments and publics have become increasingly aware of and determined to counteract Russian hostile measures campaigns – variations of which are sometimes also referred to as active measures, hybrid warfare, gray zone operations, low-intensity conflict, and other terms. While Russia is the most well-known, sophisticated, and prolific hostile measures actor in Europe, it is far from the only one. An array of foreign governments seek to influence policy and
publics in Europe to achieve their foreign policy aims via overt and covert means. China’s campaigns have become more visible recently, whether its “Wolf Warrior” diplomacy or its campaigns to win influence using economic tools like the Belt and Road Initiative or PPE donations during the COVID-19 pandemic. Other actors such as Turkey and the Gulf states mount campaigns with more limited aims in places like the Western Balkans. This course will explore the actors who mount hostile measures campaigns in Europe, assess their aims, and evaluate their success – or failure. We will identify the tools and tactics they employ and analyze how these campaigns manifest in case studies drawn from across Europe. Finally, we will seek to understand and formulate counter-influence strategies that can enable European governments and other actors to blunt or immunize their societies against hostile measures campaigns.

It has been a pretty rough ride so far in the twenty-first century. What may have started with grand hopes for a glorious future as the world celebrated the advent of a new millennium on New Year’s Eve 1999 has so far, at least according to a widespread perception among people
in the “West,” unfolded as a series of crises: 9/11 and the global “war on terror”; the devastating financial crisis of 2007-8; Brexit, the rise of rightwing “populism,” and the crisis of liberal democracy; the Covid-19 pandemic… Have we entered The Age of Crisis? In this course, we will explore the history of what is not history yet. We will investigate the very recent past and the ways contemporaries on either side of the Atlantic have tried to make sense of the first decades of the twenty-first century from a historical perspective. The goal is  to situate the most recent developments in society, politics, and culture in a longer-term historical context and examine the central ideas and forces that shape the present – such as neoliberalism, globalization, ethno-nationalism, populism, polarization, the “culture wars” – from a historicizing perspective. More generally, we also want to reflect on the question of how the historical approach can contribute to a better understanding of the present: How does history relate to the present? How does the study of history influence our understanding of our current moment? And what, if anything, can we “learn” from history as we are navigating
the crises and challenges of the twenty-first century?

Two years have passed and we already know that yesterday's world has vanished with more than 175 million people infected and about 4 million dead from COVID-19. The transformation of politics and international relations has accelerated, and the trends that had previously been identified seem to be undergoing consolidation. We can point to some milestones along the way, such as the decline of the multilateral system, the weak position of the EU, the growing disinterest in liberal ideals, the new political cycle in Latin America, the rise of China, economic de-globalisation, inequality, the gender perspective, and the digital transformation. None of these issues is so new that it merits the term “pandemic diplomacy” with regard to the academic study and practice of diplomatic endeavours, yet it represents a starting point for in-depth analysis of the consequences of such issues on the international system and the diplomatic profession.

This course explores the political, social, cultural, and intellectual transformations in the wake of the Cold War’s end, from the late 1980s through the early 2000s. The focus is on North America and Western Europe, as well as on the developments in the former Eastern bloc and the reconfiguration of the international system. We want to investigate the search for a new global order and the ways in which contemporaries tried to make sense of the post-Cold War world, the key intellectual currents, and the distinct (political, social, and pop-) culture that emerged in the 1990s – thereby examining the rise of the present after what observers at the time briefly thought was the “the end of history.”

In recent decades, the social and economic landscapes of Western democracies have undergone profound changes. From economic re-structuring and global recessions to demographic change, these transformations have deeply impacted the politics, policy strategies, and political outcomes of today’s most affluent industrialized societies. This course uses the tools of comparative political economy to understand the political origins and consequences of these transformations. We will cover questions such as: how do de-industrialization, globalization, and the transition to knowledge societies re-shape party competition and electoral choices? What are the economic underpinnings of popular dissatisfaction with politics and mainstream party decline? How do rising income and wealth inequalities restructure political conflict? What explains preferences for redistribution and social policies in an age of rising immigration and aging populations and how do governments (struggle to) adequately respond to urgent contemporary challenges like climate change?

Global Governance in an Era of Great Power Rivalry. Global governance is the way countries
engage with each other to solve big problems collectively that no single state can fix. Against the
current backdrop of wars, famine, climate change, pandemics, and other crises, effective systems
of global governance – which require cooperation and compromise – have never been more
important. Great power rivalry affects global governance acutely. The Biden Administration
has committed to “relentless diplomacy” in the multilateral space. China is asserting its interests
abroad with increasing vigor. Russia is embroiled in a UN Charter-busting war with its
neighbor. And the European Union is striving to become a geopolitical force. Will these powers’
often contrasting global visions impede collective action to confront the world’s most urgent
issues? How do medium-sized and smaller countries fit into the multilateral puzzle? Are current
systems of global governance fit for purpose? What could a successful system of global
governance look like? The course focuses on the United Nations, which at 77 remains the main
multilateral arena where the action of global governance plays out. Through case studies, with
particular emphasis on the UN Security Council, it looks in detail at the way the United States,
China, Russia, and Europe interact and pursue their interests in the fields of security,
development, climate, and human rights policy. The course will also examine other global
governance forums, such as the G20, G7, BRICS, and subregional multilateral organizations.
Most of the case studies and class content will relate to the real-life professional experiences of
the instructor. One of the major learning goals of this course is for students to gain uncommon
insights into the mechanisms, tools, and skills of multilateral diplomacy. There will be guest
speakers and simulations. This course is taught by Christopher Klein, Senior State Department
Fellow with the Institute for the Study of Diplomacy, who is on leave from the Department of
State; his most recent position was Principal Deputy Assistant Secretary for International
Organization Affairs. He has also held other senior positions at the U.S. Mission to the United
Nations and in Asia and Washington.

Popular media and political rhetoric often reference outsourcing, both as a potential source of growth and a potential source of job destruction. This course goes beyond the buzz words to examine what we really know about global production networks. What is meant by the terms “offshoring” and “outsourcing”? Are traditional models of trade sufficient to handle increasing complex global production strategies? How do we measure trade in intangibles such as intellectual property and business services? What are the impacts of offshoring on both the countries doing the investing and the countries receiving the investment? How worried should you be about losing your job to someone in India? Is the world getting “flatter”? What policy responses are appropriate? These and other related questions will be addressed using both theory and empirical evidence.

Illicit finance is a multi-trillion-dollar problem that threatens the global financial system and undermines national security and human rights in countries around the globe. This course will examine the vexing phenomenon of international financial flows (IFFs) and the need for a multi-pronged and international effort to tackle the problem. It will focus on the sources of IFFs (such as corruption, environmental crime, and looting of antiquities), how illicit funds are transferred or laundered across borders, and how these funds are ultimately used (for terrorist financing, for instance, or investment in assets such as real estate). In particular, the course will explore the role of illicit finance in sustaining kleptocracies, enabling mass atrocities, and impeding development. The course will be taught from a practitioner’s perspective and include real-world case studies on hot topics in illicit finance such as the role of professional enablers and secrecy jurisdictions; new payment methods such as cryptocurrencies; and the latest techniques in sanctions evasion. Most importantly, it will delve into the tools that governments, international bodies, and the private sector can use to combat illicit finance—and how such tools can be improved. Tracking dirty money and fighting financial crime has become an increasingly urgent priority in both the public and private sectors; the course will provide students with a hands-on, multidisciplinary introduction to this rapidly growing field.

It examines the interaction of firms and governments in the global economy, focusing on trade and investment-related measures, and the legal obligations concerning these measures. The course surveys topics ranging from protectionism (i.e., tariffs and non-tariff barriers) to rights and obligations under the World Trade Organization (WTO), to the role of bilateral investment treaties and the preferential trade agreements.

Geopolitical risks impact the operations and profitability of global businesses. Such risks can arise from conflicts among great powers, namely the United States, China, Europe, and Russia. They can also arise from ideological tensions, such as that between globalization and nationalism. Additionally, they can arise from poor country governance, such as corruption and weak rule-of-law. Risks to business operations and profitability may include physical damage, economic and financial sanctions, cyber-attacks, advanced-technology controls, tariffs, climate-related delicensing, nationalization/expropriation, anti-trust action, political censorship, public health policy actions, and capital controls, among others. This course uses data sets, as well as recent and current case studies, to provide students a grounding in how to identify, evaluate, and manage geopolitical risk exposures, as well as in how to address the impacts of geopolitical risk events as they occur.

"The Modern Global Economy: Looking Forward: Policy and Business" will provide students with an interactive, hands-on understanding of the key elements of the international economic system as well as their practical application in business and government. The course will cover four main topic areas: The Changing Nature of Global Trade; The Changing Nature of International Capital; Fostering National and Global Innovation; and Responding to Global Challenges

Instruction will be through classroom lectures, guest speakers and group and individual projects. Students will have an opportunity to participate in experiential learning activities that simulate decision-making on issues facing policy makers and business executives.

Building blocks of learning will include:
" International trade from the policymaker and business perspectives
" International finance, including financing for development
" Sustainable development, green economic development and global energy markets
" The role of innovation in economic growth in the U.S. and other countries
" The new digital marketplace, privacy, intellectual property rights and cyber security
" Successful negotiation practices and cross-cultural business communication
" Leadership in economic diplomacy and international business

A basic understanding of macro and microeconomics and political economics prior to entry in the class is strongly encouraged.

This course is an introduction of the global investment industry covering the essentials of finance, ethics, and investments. Focus is placed on understanding the characteristics of the investment profession from a practitioner’s perspective. Quantitative techniques are utilized to optimize portfolios and design investment products while the Bloomberg Market Concepts certificate program is used to familiarize students with Bloomberg analytics and functionality. In addition, simulations are incorporated to enable students to evaluate macroeconomic policies and trade equity, interest rate, commodity, currency, and bitcoin derivatives. It is ideally suited for students who want to pursue careers in investment management, investment banking, wealth management, law, compliance, or government regulation & supervision. Students who successfully complete this course will obtain the Bloomberg Market Concepts Certificate and CFA Institute Investment Foundations Certificate which demonstrate a mastery of core foundational principals of the investment profession. Description (GBUS 445 Optional Lab – 1 credit): This is an introduction to the securities industry and preparation for the FINRA Securities Industry Essentials (SIE) exam. All individuals interested in pursuing employment as representative-level registrants (e.g. analysts at banks, brokerage firms, investment managers, and wealth managers) must take the SIE. Individuals do not have to be associated with a FINRA member firm to be eligible to take the SIE. That means that students can take the SIE licensing exam while still enrolled at Georgetown. However, passing the SIE alone will not qualify an individual for registration with FINRA. An individual who has passed the SIE will also need to pass the appropriate specialized knowledge examination associated with the registration category pertaining to the individual’s job function to be eligible for registration with FINRA. Most Georgetown graduating students interested in careers in finance would take the Investment Banking Representative Exam (Series 79) or the General Securities Representative Exam (Series 7). The SIE exam began in October 2018 and students that have passed the licensing exam can demonstrate interest in the securities industry during interviews and recruiting sessions. Costs – GBUS 445 (3 credits): Approximately $75 Costs – GBUS 445 Optional Lab (1 credit): approximately $169.

This course will provide a framework for identifying the advantages to joint ventures and strategic alliances as well as the pitfalls to avoid, and will culminate in a role play in which participants negotiate terms of an alliance.

2.	Examine if a company is ready for partnership
3.	Choosing a partner and negotiating a JV or alliance

5.	Intended/unintended termination

This course will address the political economy of cities with a focus on Latin American and Asian cities. It will begin with general background, move onto issues and sectors, and then address city cases (approximately one-third each). The general background will address history, analytical tools, and cities as actors in the international system; and sectors such as transport, land use, and housing coping with the challenges of inequality, climate change, and rapid urbanization. Students should select a city with a population over 100,000 in Latin America or Asia, and have the selection approved by Prof. King. Students will be expected to follow the selected city throughout the semester, do a presentation to the class on “their” city, and produce a final paper comparing the chosen city with another city (from anywhere in the world, with both facing similar challenges), their challenges, focusing on one specific challenge, the policy responses, and results. It is strongly recommended that you can read the language of the cities in question in order to access sufficient background information, including media.

The learning objectives of the class include:
-Understanding how cities, esp. in Latin America and Asia, have developed over time.
-Understanding the dynamics of key sectors, notably transport, land use, and housing, within the broader context of urban finance and governance
-How to gather relevant data and information on cities in these regions
-Grappling with urban challenges and the policies to address them
-Presenting key challenges and policy responses of individual cities

Public Interest & Common Good: Theory and Praxis

Overview: The ‘public interest’ and ‘common good’ ('PICG') are central concepts in educated discourse about governance, the economy, ethics, philosophy and business, from Ancient Greece (and before) into the 1950s. These related concepts are embedded in most world religions and cultures, but are also misused by tyrants, ideologues, and authoritarians. In Western Civilization, they were challenged by the rise of Utilitarianism beginning in the late 18th c. and nihilism in the late-19th c., and increasingly abandoned by neoclassical economics by the 1950s, partly in response to the Cold War. By the 1980s, discourse on PICG was in disfavor in many social sciences, where it was often dismissed as vague, imprecise, unquantifiable, misused, and concealing more than it reveals. The past decade has seen a resurgence in social science research on these fundamental concepts, including in experimental social science, behavioral economics, and discourse analysis, with new research methods, techniques and approaches aiming to bring life back to this age-old discourse with applications in the private sector, government, and non-profit worlds.

The applications of these concepts in both private sector activities and public policies are vast: identifying entrepreneurial opportunities and making responsible business decisions that create both economic and social value; and defining issues, setting agendas, making decisions and implementing wise public policies. These are deep concepts on which reasonable people can disagree (reasonably) in their application to particular circumstances and issues (in business, policies, governance).

This intellectually-rich course engages students in cutting-edge research on these fundamental questions of governance and business management, applying modern research methodologies to age-old debates, while enriching students' understanding of the philosophical roots and current applications, to provide a lifelong platform for analysis and synthesis.

By the 1980s, discourse on PICG was in disfavor in many social sciences, where it was often dismissed as vague, imprecise, unquantifiable, misused, and concealing more than it reveals. The past decade has seen a resurgence in social science research on these fundamental concepts, including in experimental social science, behavioral economics, and discourse analysis, with new research methods, techniques and approaches aiming to bring life back to this age-old discourse with applications in the private sector, government, and non-profit worlds.

The applications of these concepts in both private sector activities and public policies are vast: identifying entrepreneurial opportunities and making responsible business decisions that create both economic and social value; and defining issues, setting agendas, making decisions and implementing wise public policies. These are deep concepts on which reasonable people can disagree (reasonably) in their application to particular circumstances and issues (in business, policies, governance).

This intellectually-rich course engages students in cutting-edge research on these fundamental questions of governance and business management, applying modern research methodologies to age-old debates, while enriching students' understanding of the philosophical roots and current applications, to provide a lifelong platform for analysis and synthesis.

The multilateral trading system is widely argued to be more “rules-based” than ever before. Dispute settlement under the World Trade Organization (WTO), in particular, is increasingly being called upon to adjudicate rights and obligations in international commerce. These decisions bear directly on business opportunities, both nationally and internationally. Indeed, not only do these decisions influence specific industries and trade-related measures, but the breadth and depth of “globalization” more generally. This course is about WTO dispute settlement and TradeLab is conducted under the auspices of TRADELAB, a Geneva-based NGO (see www.tradelab.org).

The course begins by examining theories of political economy, setting the stage for an in-depth look at international trade law and WTO dispute settlement and spends the entire semester working on a would-be dispute for the Office of the United States Trade Representative. The case involves health and safety standards/technical specifications concerning labels. Students will decide from among several specific applications of the measure(s) notified to the World Trade Organization. Working with USTR, including through several direct meetings, we will consult with stakeholders in the US and abroad, as well as experts in the underlying law. Previous teams of TradeLab will also be consulted.

Illicit finance is a multi-trillion-dollar problem that threatens the global financial system and undermines national security and human rights in countries around the globe. This course will examine the vexing phenomenon of international financial flows (IFFs) and the need for a multi-pronged and international effort to tackle the problem. It will focus on the sources of IFFs (such as corruption, environmental crime, looting of antiquities), how illicit funds are transferred or laundered across borders, and how these funds are ultimately used (for terrorist financing, for instance, or investment in assets such as real estate). In particular, the course will explore the role of illicit finance in sustaining kleptocracies, enabling mass atrocities, and impeding development. The course will be taught from a practitioner’s perspective and include real-world case studies on hot topics in illicit finance such as the role of professional enablers and secrecy jurisdictions; new payment methods such as cryptocurrencies; and the latest techniques in sanctions evasion. Most importantly, it will delve into the tools that governments, international bodies, and the private sector can use to combat illicit finance—and how such tools can be improved. Tracking dirty money and fighting financial crime has become an increasingly urgent priority in both the public and private sectors; the course will provide students with a hands-on, multidisciplinary introduction to this rapidly growing field.

This course provides an introduction to health and health sector issues within the context of comparative biological, social, economic and political systems. The course examines inter-sectoral issues (e.g., population, patterns of disease, environmental health and nutrition), as well as principles of comparative health systems structure, financing, and reform. The course emphasizes a comparative national-level focus, however linkages to international issues are introduced. The analytical frameworks are applicable to consideration of health issues and systems in developing, emerging, and developed economies. The course aims to build both students' mastery of concepts and theories in international health, as well as practical skills through diverse classroom approaches including: didactic methods, small group projects, case studies, and proposal writing. This course is intended to serve as the introduction to other courses in the International Health major.

This is a one-credit class that will center on structured discussions, led by Professor Monahan, with six global health leaders who will discuss both their personal career journeys and major health issues confronting our world.   
 
For each speaker, Professor Monahan will assign teams of two or three students who will prepare for, and help lead, the class conversation. Specifically, each of these lead students will (1) prepare individual briefing emails for all members of the class at least 24 hours in
advance of each conversation; (2) pose thoughtful questions for the guest global health leaders; and (3) submit a blog post on the conversation (to be posted on the Global Health Initiative website).  Following each session with a speaker, our class will convene for up to 30 minutes to discuss our reactions to the speaker. 
 

As a final project for the class, each student will prepare a reaction memo (no more than 1,000 words) that reflects on key themes that emerged in the conversations with global health leaders.  At the end of the semester, the class will convene to discuss students’ reflections on the global health leaders with whom we met, the issues that they raised, and the topics we covered.

The World Health Organization (WHO) has listed “The health impacts of climate and environmental change” as one of its four Global Public Health Priorities. 

Environment change impacts our life in many ways, including altering food safety, quality of air, and our water and sanitation systems. WHO estimates that 12.6 million people die each year as a result of living or working in an unhealthy environment. There is a spatiotemporal heterogeneity in the exposure to risks, which can be associated with the different development paths taken by countries around the world. The improvements to public health and development observed in the last decades is challenged by climate change and other global changes. The health sector plays an essential role in monitoring environmental risks and changes, and in promoting mitigation and adaptation strategies for human and health security.

Global development and increasing technological capacity have made our lives better but have also caused harmful changes to the environment and public health. This interlinkage between the local, regional, and planetary level is relevant to design effective global public health interventions.

This course introduces the complex field of global environmental health and explores many existing challenges. It also will examine the concept of planetary health and the relevance to public health of current global issues including climate change, the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and its health-related Sustainable Development Goals, and the three Rio Conventions on Biodiversity, Climate Change, and Desertification. Students will also learn about effective relationships with other disciplines and sectors, including inter-sectoral approaches in public health.

Relatively little medical research is devoted to alleviating the burden of disease affecting the overwhelming majority of the world's population. At the same time, new pharmaceutical inventions are commercialized at prices that are beyond the reach of most people in developing countries and beyond the public health budgets of the governments of these countries. This course addresses the resulting global inequity with respect to access to medicines. We will review the institutions (such as international organizations, governments, pharmaceutical companies) and market processes that determine the current state of affairs and examine all major transnational initiatives aimed at improving the situation. The tension between the high prices of patented medicines and affordability of life-saving treatment will be examined particularly, though not exclusively, in the context of antiretroviral drugs for HIV/AIDS.

With the advance in technologies, the ability to collect data has been explosively enhanced. Additionally, the world is increasingly reliant on collecting and analyzing information to make decisions across disciplines, including health. Because of this, the ability to analyze data and communicate effectively about the data is important for decision-making. This course will provide students with an overview of statistical tools that are most commonly used to process, analyze, and visualize data.  Throughout the semester, we will use R to conduct relevant analyses and visualize data with a focus on understanding how to use and interpret output from this software and how to visualize results to ease the interpretation of complex data.

This course aims to demonstrate the importance of using law (statutory, regulatory, and, where applicable, judge-made), informed by sound technical skills in science, technology, and medicine, to advance objectives relevant for both health and international relations. Further, it seeks to contextualize how and where law fits in the broader framework for global health governance. We will examine the wide range of public, private, and civil society players, institutions, and organizations that are involved in shaping, directing, and influencing global health programs, policies, and outcomes.
Law can be a powerful instrument for influencing health at the domestic, regional, and global levels. In global health, domestic and international law are interrelated and bi-directional in their impact on health and justice. Innovations in national law and policy can offer a model for other countries and regions. International law influences domestic law and policy. High-impact litigation in one jurisdiction can empower advocates in other jurisdictions to undertake similar action. Despite this, the parameters of the utility of law in global health are not clearly defined, and while some contend that “global health law” has emerged as a unique discipline – at its core, it is an amalgam of the traditional rules of international law and diplomacy combined with domestic law and policymaking. As a result, the ensuing mechanisms and actors that govern global health reflect this fluid relationship between global health, law, and governance.
Drawing from the public health framework of the social determinants of health, this course will examine law and governance through the lens of “legal determinants of health,” at both the domestic and the international levels. This approach explains how law functions as a tool to shape global health outcomes, and it explores the practical ways in which decisions are made and implemented within the governing mechanisms of important bilateral relationships (e.g., US government and other countries) and multilateral institutions (e.g., World Health Organization, Global Fund to Fight AIDS, TB and Malaria) that impact global health activities and outcomes. We will pay special attention to the leaders, venues, instruments, politics, and processes involved in global health governance; the strategies and tactics that are pursued by those involved in governing mechanisms related to health.
This course requires students to read and interpret health related legal instruments, participate in in-class simulations, and craft and present a comprehensive persuasive brief.

Infectious diseases are still the leading cause of death in low income countries and the recent COVID pandemic has impacted all countries. Infectious diseases do not respect borders and they exacerbate health inequities. Understanding the biology, epidemiology, and control of these diseases is more important now than ever.
The course will start with a general introduction to the distribution of infectious diseases and to the biological and epidemiological principles underlying their spread. The second part of the course will review all the major approaches to control, looking at specific diseases in more depth. Topics related to adapting program design to different populations, management of programs within the health system, and methods for disease surveillance and evaluation will also be covered. In the final part of the course students will discuss disease specific case studies. Throughout the course students will work in groups to apply the knowledge gained and develop disease control programs that are tailored to specific populations. The following approaches to control will be addressed: control of vector borne diseases, control of sexually transmitted diseases, vaccination and mass drug administration, Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH), behavior change, control vs elimination and eradication, and one health.

Non-Communicable Diseases in Developing Countries course focuses on the rising burden and increasing challenges associated with the shift in disease burden from infectious and communicable diseases (ICDs) to non-communicable diseases (NCDs) as the major causes of mortality, morbidity, and lost years of healthy life. It provides the students with an in-depth understanding of the challenges of NCDs and the policies and strategies to curb them in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs). The first half of the course will cover the rising global burden of NCDs in terms of total and premature deaths and the leading causes of morbidity. The students will also learn about the environmental, metabolic, and behavioral NCD risk factors such as air pollution, high blood pressure, high glucose level, alcohol, smoking and obesity. In addition, there will be an overview of the rising costs and the macro and micro-economic impact of NCDs at the state and household levels as well as the principles of behavioral economics and its relationship to NCDs. The second half of the course will present a comprehensive framework for the prevention and treatment of NCDs. This framework will cover interventions for behavior change and prevention of NCDs, and the integrated service delivery model for the effective
management of NCDs. At the end of the course, there will be a discussion on the role of the government and different sectors in adopting policies to respond to NCDs as well as the different financing models to cover them. Examples from LMICs will be presented.

Community Engagement for Social Change is an enriching, experiential course that melds theoretical knowledge with practical skills, empowering students to lead transformative community-based initiatives. The course delves into the nuances of community-based theories and strategies, the intricacies of acquiring genuine community buy-in, and the practicalities of diagnosing community challenges, crafting action plans, and conducting impactful evaluations. Students will navigate the intricate dynamics of community contexts, learning to facilitate inclusive dialogues and drive collective action, while honing their skills in monitoring, feedback utilization, and continuous improvement of initiatives. A significant emphasis of the course is on fostering cultural competence, ensuring students can effectively engage with diverse communities, respect cultural differences, and employ culturally sensitive approaches to problem-solving. Upon course completion, students will have a holistic understanding of community engagement for social change, underpinned by a keen awareness of cultural diversity and its implications for community work. They will also possess a practical, ready-to-implement community engagement blueprint, tailored to respect and address the unique cultural contexts of the communities they serve

The objective of this course is to provide a current picture of the landscape of global health financing, both at domestic and international level, and to explain how the financing tools being used work.

This block seminar will look at both the broad context and the practical issues related to planning, costing, and budgeting in the health sector. Specifically, the course will examine how governments:
•	mobilize sufficient financial resources by: (i) estimating program and project costs for given outputs of services; and (ii) identifying the sources and characteristics of funding to provide these services;
•	allocate these resources consistent with: (i) priorities established in health sector policies, plans, and operational directives; and (ii) management of the budgetary process in a strategic and skillful manner; and 
•	disburse the authorized amounts effectively and efficiently, that is: (i) on the budgeted activities/items; (ii) in accordance with the approved plan to achieve the planned objectives; and (iii) within the proposed time period.
The seminar will address the context for planning and budgeting in developing countries, the sources and characteristics of health sector financing, planning, costing considerations and techniques, management of the budgetary process, as well as budget performance and accountability.

Key questions range from “what shall we evaluate and is this program or policy working?” to “how and why is it working?”, “is it efficient”, and “can we do better?”.  Through a wide selection of readings and case studies, students will gain an overview of the field of evaluation, learn specific applied skills in quantitative evaluation methods, as well as techniques and common pitfalls in interpreting, presenting and using the results.  The course exposes students to the most innovative and advanced evaluation skills used in the field today, as well as to on-going debates over the application and effectiveness of these techniques.   The course is participatory in nature, and students will be engaged in hands-on exercises involving evaluation design and interpretation of results. [open only to GHD students]

The purpose of this course is to provide students with a conceptual framework and analytical tools, rooted in microeconomic theory, to design and evaluate policies aimed at reducing poverty and inequality in developing countries. After an overview of the measurement of poverty and inequality and recent trends, we will present the framework of market failures and government failures that explain these phenomena and suggest policies to address them. We will then examine interventions to reduce poverty and inequality along three dimensions: (i) expanding economic opportunities, especially employment; (ii) enhancing human capital, especially health and education; and (iii) protecting vulnerable populations from shocks. The course will conclude by applying the framework to four topics that are especially relevant to reducing poverty and inequality: (i) fragility and conflict; (ii) gender; (iii) urbanization; and (iv) politics.

The course is designed to provide a practical understanding of the new ways being used to correct environmental problems through conservation, improved land management, and ecosystem restoration. Through discussion and examination of real-world examples, students will explore how these methods affect the reduction of greenhouse gases and promote the increase storage of carbon globally. We will also discuss the effects that these methods may have on developing nations and if these practices are equitable across all income levels. Globally we are on a race against time to reverse the disastrous effects that rising carbon levels are causing. Governments around the world have committed to making measurable change to reduce carbon emission by 2030, but is this achievable? Climate change affects everyone, but is disproportionately affecting economic disadvantaged communities. The goal is to save the environment while not doing harm to populations that are vulnerable.

In this course, we will learn what is meant by natural climate solutions and how this differs from previous practices. We will examine the following questions: Are these practices accessible to all countries and income levels? Can practices be good for the environment, but also bad for society? Is there bias, nationalism, or racism baked into these proposed solutions? What is the role of technology in implementing these solutions? How can these practices help communities adapt to climate change?
This course has students (working alone or in a small group) to discuss and debate strategies for problems posed. Classes will be highly interactive and will challenge students to broaden their perspective and make them more effective practitioners in international development.

Geospatial technologies include a suite of inter-connected technologies, such as geographic information systems (GIS) and remote sensing technologies (e.g. satellite imagery). These technologies have emerged in recent decades as cross-cutting, enabling, and prevalent in all aspects of life. This course primarily focuses on illustrating how GIS is enabling decision makers and professionals in understanding the needs of our rapidly changing, extremely diverse, yet ever more interconnected world. This course is designed primarily for graduate students who aspire to be leaders in the public, private, and non-profit sectors of international affairs and global development. Graduate students interested in international development, global politics and security, global human development, reducing poverty, global public health, and humanitarian/crisis management are welcome to join this course. Special attention will be put on the importance of ethics and best practices in applying GIS and other related technologies in these fields.

In many low- and middle-income countries (LMICs), agri-food systems can be instrumental not only in reducing poverty and hunger, but also in ensuring sustainable food and nutrition security; healthy populations and environment; efficient use of resources, and resilience to shocks and crises. The objective of this course is to introduce students to the concept of agri-food systems, their role in economic development, why and how they should/ could be transformed to be sustainable, resilient and inclusive in providing livelihoods and nutritious food for current and future generations. The course will focus on topics such as global trends in food demand and supply; the roles of organizations, institutions, policy and technology, and shocks and crises effecting/caused by agri-food systems (such as climate change and COVID-19), and will highlight national, regional and global level opportunities and challenges for LMICs to transform their agri-food systems. In addition to providing the theoretical framework and the latest literature on each topic, each session will also feature an invited guest lecturer/expert from the field, as well as a case study so as to make the topics and working thereon more relatable and accessible to those who may want to work in this field.

This course is about challenges for education systems in the 21st century. Education places a critical role in development and poverty reduction. This course explores the links between education and development and the progress that has been achieved in education. It then explores some of the key challenges of improving the quality of education, strengthening the transition from primary to secondary school, the links to the job markets, building strong education institutions, and other key challenges.

The course will explore investments in major renewable energy projects in developing countries in the context of navigating the clean energy transition to address climate mitigation and adaptation. It will provide a practitioner’s perspective for making investment decisions by analyzing a series of applied global case studies taught through a multimedia approach. Students will be exposed to all stages of a project development cycle, from design and appraisal through implementation to post evaluation of investment performance. They will also gain an understanding of how international finance and development institutions operate in this space. The classes will expose students to the application of a variety of analytical techniques and methods that underpin investment decisions, including financial valuation, economic justification of interventions, distributional impacts on key stakeholders, stochastic risk analysis (Monte Carlo), valuation of environmental externalities, assessment of power system vulnerabilities, cost-benefit analysis (CBA), qualitative comparative analysis (QCA), (Delphi) forecasting utilizing expert opinions, and multi-method performance evaluation. Prior knowledge of these approaches is not required as students will be provided with a short primer and related multimedia information to familiarize them with applicable methods and techniques prior to each case-study discussion.

This course is designed to create a rich intellectual environment where students develop the necessary skills to produce an applied econometrics paper of publishable quality in the field of international development. The principal learning goals are (1) quasi-experimental research design and estimation methods using large-sample microdata and (2) the writing, critique, and presentation of evidence-based policy analysis. To achieve these objectives, students have two roles in the workshop: the author of their own paper and the peer reviewer for a classmate. Students work individually with an external advisor—a professor or practitioner whose expertise coincide with their chosen topic. The course instructor acts as a second reader with whom the student can consult on methodological, data, and coding issues.

Most countries consider fighting poverty as a priority. However, policies that should be effective in generating positive development outcomes are often not adopted, are poorly implemented, or end up backfiring over time. Traditional economics mainly studies what policies and interventions are needed to generate better outcomes, often framing the analysis as interventions aimed at fixing market failures, or at promoting redistribution. Much less attention has been given to learning why those approaches succeed so well in some contexts but fail to generate positive results in others. This course examines why well-intended and well-designed anti-poverty policies remain so often ineffective. In particular, in this course poverty and prosperity are intended as the result of the interaction between state and non-state actors, institutions and social norms. The course will discuss how development issues such as conflict, lack of economic growth, and poverty can be interpreted as the outcome of governance failures, defined as power asymmetries, in the form of exclusion, elite capture, clientelism. Finally, it will discuss how change can be brought about to break vicious cycles and foster prosperity.

The course is designed to provide a practical understanding of the relationship between development and environmental issues, using real world examples and experiences, to showcase how western ideologies and biases have and continue to affect environmental perspectives and resource use across the global South. Developing countries are at crossroads today. On one hand, they want to pursue development-oriented policies that have often delivered the promise of economic prosperity and social progress to millions around the world. At the same time, these countries are also being disproportionately affected by adverse environmental conditions and the outcomes of climate change.



In this course, we will think about how our perception is shaped based on where we live and the societal values we embrace. We will examine the following questions: How does need change with the development process? Can development be bad for the environment, but also good for society? What are examples of hypocrisy (real or perceived) in how western nations interact with their southern neighbors when addressing environmental issues? What is the role of government in addressing those barriers? What conflicts may arise or could be avoided related to natural resource allocation. We will also look at how technology and migration transform landscapes, affect development, and increase natural resource use.

This course will focus on both the theory and the practice of cost-benefit analysis in the context of international development.  Students will learn cost-benefit analysis modeling techniques to estimate financial and economic returns of development interventions.  The course will explore concepts such as time preference, discounting, net present value, internal rate of return and points of view.   Students will learn how to test key project assumptions through sensitivity analysis and risk analysis.  Case studies and hands-on examples will be used to illustrate the application of cost-benefit concepts in several sectors, such as agriculture, power and roads.

This course explores the role of government in countries around the world and the government financing and provision of public goods and services. The course has three goals: First, it aims to teach students key concepts in public finance, including externalities, public goods, social insurance and redistribution. Second, it will compare countries and regions around the world in terms of the size of governments, their expenditures, revenues and deficits, the structure of taxes and expenditures, and the efficiency and equity of government operations. Third, it will introduce students to analytical tools and techniques in public finance analysis. This will include the economic analysis of public projects; empirical approaches for assessing the progressivity of taxes and expenditures; tools for assessing the efficiency of public expenditures; etc. The course expects to develop the following skills and knowledge: knowledge of key concepts in public finance; knowledge of analytical tools and techniques; and technical and practical skills in the analysis of government operations.

People say you are what you eat. Can what we eat change the world? Today’s food system is not fit for purpose - it produces more than enough food, yet there are more people living in hunger than ever before, it is a leading source of GHG emissions, biodiversity loss, environmental degradation, unhealthy diets, and a large share of people that run it live in poverty. This course explores the public policies and investments necessary to bend the arc of the food system to deliver healthy people, a healthy economy, and a healthy planet. Students will learn to apply economic and financial cost benefit analysis techniques to public policies and investment in the food system. Each student will undertake a case study tailored to their specific area of interest of the food system (food security, nutrition, agriculture, biodiversity, climate change, etc.

Social protection (SP) is the field of study that examines policies and programs to prepare societies and individuals to manage socio-economic risks. SP aims to protect people from a range of shocks, including those caused by economic crises, pandemics, chronic poverty and climate change. SP also seeks to provide people with opportunities to build a better life for themselves and their families. This course will provide students with an overview of the major concepts and policy instruments in the area of SP, covering social insurance, social assistance, safety nets and labor. This includes cash transfers (conditional and unconditional), in-kind transfers (seeds, fertilizer, school feeding, etc.), fee waivers and scholarships, public works, old age pensions, and programs for specific vulnerable populations. Second, the course will examine social protection systems and delivery mechanisms, including targeting, payments, monitoring and evaluation. Country case studies will be used to illustrate how these concepts and instruments are applied in practice by policymakers.

This course has two main learning objectives. First, to equip students with the key theoretical, analytical and practical skills and frameworks used in the field of social protection. Second, to enable students to approach the assessment, design, implementation, and evaluation of SP programs and schemes both at the country and specific program level in a systematic, evidence-based manner. The course is organized as an interactive seminar, with a premium on student participation.

Increasingly, development innovation and social service and product delivery are being initiated by the private sector, in particular with a focus on projects that are sustainable, scalable and with a positive social or environmental impact. The private sector, both domestic and international, now holds the largest slice of the global development contribution pie.  What roles does the private sector play, and how might their impact be maximized?  The role of the for-profit sector in social value creation will be examined, with particular attention to impact investing, impact bonds/pay for performance schemes, intrapreneurship, corporate social responsibility initiatives, and public-private partnerships.

Small and medium enterprises or “SMEs” represent a large share of developing countries’ private sectors. The support and promotion of their development is, therefore, an intuitive reaction of international development actors. Yet, many challenges arise when establishing the target, type, and level of intervention. Targets can be unclear due to country-specific definitions, often lacking statistics and data due to the heterogeneity and informal character of SMEs. Interventions can be financial or technical and their focus can vary widely, from poverty reduction to economic growth. They can address SME-internal, sector-specific or countrywide issues. Furthermore, the most appropriate actor to lead the intervention may be the national government, the subnational administration, business associations, NGOs, international donors and organizations, or the private sector. 

Recently, a new dynamic that integrates business-management approaches related to organization, process, or service models into human-development efforts has gained momentum. Many of these new ideas are tested and promoted by small enterprises. Thus, the course will look at private sector and SME development as an objective, the private sector as an actor for development, and business management as a toolbox for innovative development ideas.
